sen.j: 在地領主（ざいちりょうしゅ）とは、中世日本の荘園公領制の下で在地（現地）において農民・漁民らを実際に支配する権限を持った領主のこと。
sen.e: Local lord (在地領主: Zaichiryoshu) is a lord having the authority to control the farmers and fishermen in his local territory (at site) by executing the real power under the Shoen koryo sei (the System of Public Lands and Private Estates) in the Medieval Japan.

A Zaichiryoshu was a local lord with the authority to control farmers and fishermen in his territory by executing authority under the Shoen koryo sei (System of Public Lands and Private Estates) in Medieval Japan.
sen.cmt: article usage, removed some unhelpful explanations
sen.e: A local lord (or "Zaichi ryoshu" in Japanese) is an appropriator with the authority to control farmers and fishermen in his territory by executing authority under the Shoen koryo sei (System of Public Lands and Private Estates) in Medieval Japan.
sen.cmt: 統一リスト（その他 2009/6/29）の指示により、Zaichiryoshu を "Zaichi ryoshu" に修正しました。A Zaichiryoshu was a local lord をA local lord (or "zaichi ryoshu" in Japanese) is an appropriator に修正しました。※8列目の「在池領主制 (Zaichi ryoshu sei)」で "zaichi ryoshu" が再度出てくるため、ここで上記のとおり説明しておくのが一番解り易いと思われました。

sen.j: 都市部に拠点を有する貴族や寺社などの荘園領主（都市領主）や公領における国守や知行国主などと対比される存在である。
sen.e: His presence was compared to the lord of the manor (shoen) belonging to the nobility and the temples and shrines that had their base in the urban areas (urban lords), or Kokukshu (head of provincial governors) and Chigyo-kokushu (provincial proprietor) in the public lands.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。 都市領主→定訳不明：urban lordsとしました。
sen.e: His position was in contrast to the lord of the manor (shoen), who belonged to the nobility, and the temples and shrines that had their base in the urban areas (urban lords), or Kokushu (head of provincial governors) and Chigyo-kokushu (provincial proprietor) in the public lands.
sen.cmt: spellingcompared->contrast
sen.e: His position was in contrast to the lord of the manor (shoen), who belonged to the nobility, and the temples and shrines that had their base in the urban areas (urban lords), or Kokushu (head of provincial governors) and Chigyo-kokushu (provincial proprietor) in the public lands.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 一般的には当時の記録では「根本領主」「開発領主」と呼ばれ、村落に宅（屋敷地）を持つ武士層が想定されている。
sen.e: And according to the records of that time, it was supposed to belong, in general, to the samurai class, and was the proprietor of the house unit (residential compound), and they were called 'Konpon ryoshu' (local lord with fundamental ruling right), 'Kaihatsu-ryoshu, '(local lord who developed the land) and others.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。 宅→定訳不明：house unitとしました。
sen.e: And according to the records of the time, they were generally members of the samurai class, served as proprietor of a house, and were called 'Konpon ryoshu' (local lord with fundamental ruling right) or 'Kaihatsu-ryoshu, ' (local lord who developed the land).
sen.cmt: shortened to improve clarity
sen.e: And according to the records of the time, they were generally members of the samurai class, served as proprietor of a house, and were called 'Konpon ryoshu' (local lord with fundamental ruling right) or 'Kaihatsu-ryoshu, ' (local lord who developed the land).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: なお、在地領主による土地支配体制を在池領主制（ざいちりょうしゅせい）と呼称する。
sen.e: And the Land ruling system by the local lord is called Zaichi ryoshu sei (the local lord system).
sen.cmt: 在池領主制（ざいちりょうしゅせい）→定訳不明：Zaichi ryoshu sei (the local lord system)としました。なお在池領主制→在地領主制と考えて訳しました。
sen.e: Furthermore, the system for control of land by local lords was called Zaichi ryoshu sei.
sen.cmt: and->furthermore
sen.e: Furthermore, the system for control of land by local lords was called "Zaichi ryoshu sei."
sen.cmt: 統一リスト（その他 2009/6/29）の指示により、Zaichi ryoshu sei. にダブルクォーテーションを追記しました。

sen.j: 在地領主は在地に宅と呼ばれる居住空間とそれに付属する門田畠と呼ばれる直営地を保有していた。
sen.e: The local lord had his living space (residence) and its adjacent directly-managed farming land called Kadotabata (門田畠) in his local land.
sen.cmt: 門田畠→Kadotabata (門田畠) [正しい読み方が不明です]
sen.e: The local lord had his residence and adjacent farm land, called Kadotabata, in his local land.
sen.cmt: removed confusing and unnecessary parenthetical explanations
sen.e: The local lord had his residence and adjacent farm land, called Kadotabata, in his local land.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 在地領主は都市の荘園領主から一定の制約を受けながらも宅や門田畠によって構成される本宅（堀ノ内・土居）に関する強力な私権を有し、郎従・下人を従えていた。
sen.e: The local lord had a strong private authority over his residential compound (Horinouchi/Doi) composed of his residence and farming land, even under a certain restriction imposed by the lord of the manor, followed by roju (vassals) and genin (lower ranked people).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The local lord had strong private authority over his residential compound (Horinouchi/Doi), which was composed of his residence and farm land, even under restrictions imposed by the lord of the manor, followed by roju (vassals) and genin (lower ranked people).
sen.cmt: shortened to improve clarity
sen.e: The local lord had strong private authority over his residential compound (Horinouchi/Doi), which was composed of his residence and farm land, even under restrictions imposed by the lord of the manor, followed by roju (vassals) and genin (lower ranked people).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 本宅内に彼らの小屋や、馬屋・馬場・弓場・堀・土塁、種子や農具などを保管する倉庫などの施設を設けて防御を固めた。
sen.e: His residential compound was equipped with the huts of roju and genin, as well as a stable, riding ground, training hall of bow, moat, mound, and a storage to keep seeds and farming utensils, to provide protection.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: For protection, his residential compound was equipped with houses for roju and genin, as well as a stable, riding ground, bow and arrow training hall, moat, mound, and storage for seeds and farming implements.
sen.cmt: utensils->implements
sen.e: For protection, his residential compound was equipped with houses for roju and genin, as well as a stable, riding ground, bow and arrow training hall, moat, mound, and storage for seeds and farming implements.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 本宅を囲う堀は本宅の防御とともに門田畠への灌漑機能も合わせて有していたことから、荘園内において高い生産力を持つことが可能となった。
sen.e: The moat constructed around the residence, which not only provided protection for the residence but also served as an irrigation, enabled the local lord to enjoy a high productivity in the manor.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The moat constructed around the residence, which not only provided protection but also served as irrigation, enabled the local lord to enjoy high productivity in the manor.
sen.cmt: “for the residence” was redundant
sen.e: The moat constructed around the residence, which not only provided protection but also served as irrigation, enabled the local lord to enjoy high productivity in the manor.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 在地領主は本宅を拠点として、その軍事的・経済的基盤を背景に勧農・検注・夫役徴収などの権限を行使し、後には公領所職や荘園荘官（下司・公文）の地位を獲得した。
sen.e: The local lord with the residents as his home base, made use of his authorities, such as agricultural promotion (kanno), land survey (kenchu), and labor service and tax collection backed by his military and economical infrastructures, and afterwards, the local lord came to take the post of Koryojo (an officer of Imperial demesne) or the position of Shoen sokan (officers governing shoen (manor), including geshi (lower ranked officers to operate a manor) and kumon (a local shoen officials below the geshi in rank)).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。 勧農→定訳不明：agricultural promotion (kanno)としました。 夫役徴収→定訳不明： labor service and tax collection としました。
sen.e: With the residence as his home base, the local lord exercised his authority, such as in the promotion of agriculture (kanno), land survey (kenchu), and labor service and tax collection backed by his military and economic infrastructure, and afterwards, the local lord came to take the post of Koryojo (an officer of Imperial demesne) or the position of Shoen sokan (officers governing manors, including geshi and kumon).
sen.cmt: spellingremoved excess explanations and nested parentheses
sen.e: With the residence as his home base, the local lord exercised his authority, such as in the promotion of agriculture (kanno), land survey (kenchu), and labor service and tax collection backed by his military and economic infrastructure, and afterwards, the local lord came to take the post of Koryojo (an officer of Imperial demesne) or the position of Shoen shokan (officers governing manors, including geshi and kumon).
sen.cmt: Shoen sokan を Shoen shokan に修正しました。

sen.j: 検断や年貢公事の収取権限をも獲得するようになった在地領主は在地における実質的な支配者となった。
sen.e: And the land lord became a practical governor in the local land, having acquired even such rights as the right to judge criminal cases, and the right to collecting and receiving nengu (land tax) and ordering koji (public duties).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。 検断→the right to judge criminal cases 収取権限→定訳不明：the right to collecting and receiving nengu (land tax) and ordering koji (public duties)としました。 年貢→nengu (land tax) 公事→koji (public duties).
sen.e: The land lord thus became a practical governor, and acquired such rights as the right to judge criminal cases, and the right to collect land tax and order koji (public duties).
sen.cmt: shortened to improve clarity
sen.e: The land lord thus became a practical governor, and acquired such rights to judge criminal cases, to collect land tax and to order koji (public duties).
sen.cmt: such rights as the right to judge criminal cases, and the right to collect land tax and order koji (public duties). をand acquired such rights to judge criminal cases, to collect land tax and to order koji (public duties). に修正しました。

sen.j: 後世において御家人あるいは「村落領主」「国人領主」へと飛躍することとなった。
sen.e: In posterity, it turned into gokenin (an immediate vassal of the shogunate) or "Sonraku ryoshu" (rural lord) and "Kokujin ryoshu" (local samurai lord).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。「村落領主」→定訳不明："Sonraku ryoshu"(rural lord)としました。
sen.e: Later on, it developed into gokenin (an immediate vassal of the shogunate), or "Sonraku ryoshu" (rural lord) and "Kokujin ryoshu" (local samurai lord).
sen.cmt: “posterity” is inappropriate in this context
sen.e: Later on, it developed into gokenin (an immediate vassal of the shogunate), or 'Sonraku ryoshu' (rural lord) and 'Kokujin ryoshu' (local samurai lord).
sen.cmt: ダブルクォーテーションをシングルクォーテーションに修正しました。

tit.cmt: Local lord system を Land Lord System に修正しました。

sen.j: 中世に入ると、貴族や寺社などの都市領主層が次第に没落し、武士が政治社会の実権を握っていく時代とする認識は古くから存在した。
sen.e: It has been long recognized that during the middle ages, the urban lord class such as the nobilities and the temples and shrines had gradually declined, and the samurai class had extended their real power in the political and social spheres.

It has been long recognized that during the middle ages, the urban lord class such as the nobility and the temples and shrines had gradually declined, and the samurai class had extended their real power in the political and social spheres.
sen.cmt: made “nobility” singular
sen.e: It has been long recognized that during the middle ages, the urban lord class such as the nobility and the temples and shrines had gradually declined, and the samurai class had extended their real power in the political and social spheres.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: しかし、戦後になって石母田正が『中世的世界の形成』を著し、武士が在地領主として在地を支配していく過程と貴族・寺社による古代奴隷制国家の解体と武士による中世封建制国家の形成を関連付ける「在地領主制」の考え方を打ち出した。
sen.e: However, after World War II, Tadashi I SHIMODA wrote "Chuseiteki Sekai no Keisei" (The formation of the medieval world) and presented the idea of Zaichi ryoshu sei (the local lord system) that relates the process of the dismantling the ancient nation with the institution of slavery sustained by the nobilities and the temples and shrines, with the formation of the medieval nation with feudal system supported by the samurai class.
sen.cmt: 石母田正→Tadashi I SHIMODA 『中世的世界の形成』"Chuseiteki Sekai no Keisei" (The formation of the medieval world) 古代奴隷制国家→定訳不明 ：ancient nation with the institution of slavery としました。 中世封建制国家→定訳不明： medieval nation with feudal systemとしました。
sen.e: However, after World War II, Tadashi I SHIMODA wrote "Chuseiteki Sekai no Keisei" (The formation of the medieval world) and presented the idea of Zaichi ryoshu sei (the local lord system) that relates the process of the dismantling the ancient nation with the institution of slavery sustained by the nobility and the temples and shrines, with the formation of the medieval nation with a feudal system supported by the samurai class.
sen.cmt: number, articles
sen.e: However, after World War II, Tadashi I SHIMODA wrote "Chuseiteki Sekai no Keisei" (The formation of the medieval world) and presented the idea of 'Zaichi ryoshu sei' (the local lord system) that relates the process of the dismantling the ancient nation with the institution of slavery sustained by the nobility and the temples and shrines, with the formation of the medieval nation with a feudal system supported by the samurai class.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。原文「が、戦後になって」を「しかし、戦後になって」に変更しました。Zaichi ryoshu sei にシングルクォーテーションを追記しました。

sen.j: 石母田の考えは日本史学に大きな影響力を与え、在地領主と武家政権（鎌倉幕府・室町幕府）成立史を結びつける研究や在地領主の形成と解体の過程を平安時代後期から戦国時代 (日本)に探る動きなどの動きが見られ、反対に石母田説への批判論（在地領主を奴隷制支配者と捉える説や荘園領主の被官に過ぎないとする説などの「非領主論説」）も含めた活発な議論が行われた。
sen.e: The idea of Ishimoda, which gave a big impact to the studies of Japanese history, arose a series of active researches and discussions, including the studies that related local lord with the history of the military governments （Kamakura bakufu and Muromachi bakufu）formation, the efforts to trace the process of formation and dismantling of the local lords class from the late Heian Period to the Sengoku period (period of warring states), as well as, the criticisms against the Ishimoda theory (a theory that defined the local lord as the dominator of the slavery, and a theory known as 'non-lord theory,' which argued that the local lord was a mere officer in charge under the lord of the manor (shoen)).
sen.cmt: 「非領主論説」→定訳不明：'non-lord theory' としました。
sen.e: Ishimoda's idea, which had a big impact on the study of Japanese history, gave rise to much active research and discussion, including studies that related local lords with the formation of military governments (Kamakura bakufu and Muromachi bakufu), efforts to trace the process of rise and decline of local lords from the late Heian Period to the Sengoku period, as well as criticisms against the Ishimoda theory (which defined the local lord as a slave master, as well the 'non-lord theory,' which argued that the local lord was a mere officer in charge under the lord of the manor).
sen.cmt: this sentence was a mess. I cleaned it up a little
sen.e: Ishimoda's idea, which had a big impact on the study of Japanese history, gave rise to much active research and discussion, including studies that related local lords with the formation of military governments (the Kamakura bakufu and the Muromachi bakufu), efforts to trace the process of rise and decline of local lords from the late Heian Period to the Sengoku period, as well as criticisms against the Ishimoda theory (which defined the local lord as a slave master, as well the 'non-lord theory,' which argued that the local lord was a mere officer in charge under the lord of the manor).
sen.cmt: Kamakura bakufu, Muromachi bakufu にそれぞれ定冠詞 the を追記しました。

sen.j: 1970年代に入ると、在地領主の研究の進展に従い石母田の理論のみでは在地領主を十分には捉えきれないとする指摘が出されるようになった。
sen.e: In 1970's, with the advancement of the studies on the land lord, some scholars started to point out that the Ishimoda theory was not enough to capture the whole picture of the land lord.
In the 1970s, with the advancement of the research on land lords, some scholars started to point out that the Ishimoda theory was not enough to capture the whole picture.
sen.cmt: misused apostrophe, last “of the land lord” was redundant”
sen.e: In the 1970s, with the advancement of the research on local lords, some scholars started to point out that the Ishimoda theory was not enough to capture the whole picture.
sen.cmt: 在地領主land lords を local lords に修正しました。

sen.j: 例えば、在地の流通機構への支配拡大や地縁的・血縁的結合を利用することで広範な地域支配者としての国人領主へと転換していく者と反対に在地領主が村落内部において再生産されていく村落領主と称すべき土豪・名主層に分けられることが明らかとなってきた。
sen.e: For example, it was gradually revealed that the land lords could be divided into two types; those who were transforming into Kokujin ryoshu, as an extensive regional dominator, by making use of his enhanced control over the local distribution system, as well as, the local connections and kinship, and the others so called Sonraku ryoshu, such as local ruling families and nanushi (village headmen), who were the local lords having been reproduced within the rural communities.

For example, it was gradually revealed that the land lords could be divided into two types - those who transformed into Kokujin ryoshu and dominated a wide region by controlling local distribution systems and local kinship connections, and the so-called Sonraku ryoshu, such as local ruling families and village headmen, who were the equivalent of local lords within rural communities.
sen.cmt: this translator seems to like unnecessarily long expressions, and explanations that are not present in the original text
sen.e: For example, it was gradually revealed that the local lords could be divided into two types - those who transformed into Kokujin ryoshu who dominated a wide region by controlling local distribution systems and local kinship connections, and those so-called Sonraku ryoshu, such as local ruling families and village headmen, who were the equivalent of local lords within rural communities.
sen.cmt: the land lords を the local lords に修正しました。Kokujin ryoshu and dominated a wide region… をKokujin ryoshu who dominated a wide region に修正しました。and the so-called Sonraku ryoshu をand those so-called Sonraku ryoshu に修正しました。

sen.j: 更に武士が必ずしも在地領主であった訳ではない事例や在地領主ではない在地居住の武士（「村の侍」）の存在、そして領主に支配される在地の民衆が必ずしも支配を甘受するだけの存在ではなく主体的・自律的性格を併せ持った存在であったことなども指摘されるようになった。
sen.e: Moreover, some researches started to point out: the cases showing that the samurai was not always equal to the local lord, the existence of local lords who were not local resident samurais (rural samurais), and the fact that the local people who were supposed to be dominated by the land lord were not always the being that were only bearing hardship under the control, but were the existence with an autonomous and self-determined character.

Moreover, some researches pointed out that the evidence showing that samurai were not always equal to the local lord, the existence of local lords who were not local resident samurais, and the fact that the local people who were supposed to be dominated by the land lord did not always bear hardship, but were autonomous and self-determined.
sen.cmt: shortened to improve clarity
sen.e: Moreover, some researches pointed out that the evidence showing that samurai were not always equal to the local lord, the existence of local lords who were not local resident samurais, and the fact that the local people who were supposed to be dominated by the local lord did not always bear hardship, but were autonomous and self-determined.
sen.cmt: the land lord を the local lord に修正しました。

sen.j: また、在地領主の支配の権限を職の体系と結びつける考え方、私的な「イエ」支配の延長線上に捉える考え方、地域の安全保障・公共機能の支配・維持者である「長老」としての役割を重視する考えかたなどを重視する考え方なども出されることとなった。
sen.e: Also, the following ideas were presented: the idea to make the linkage between the land lord's authority to control and the job system, the idea to look at it as an extension of the control by 'Ie' (Japanese private family system), the idea to place the emphasis on its role as a 'wise old man,' who was the controller and manager of the local security and public function, among others

Also, the following ideas were presented: to link the land lord's authority to control over the job system, to look at it as an extension of control by 'Ie' (Japanese private family system), to place emphasis on its role as a 'wise elder,' who was managed local security and public functions.
sen.cmt: shortened to improve clarity
sen.e: Also, the following ideas were presented: to link the local lord's authority to control over the job system, to look at it as an extension of control by 'Ie' (Japanese private family system), to place emphasis on its role as a 'wise elder,' who was managed local security and public functions.
sen.cmt: to link the land lord's authority をto link the local lord's authority に修正しました。

sen.j: そして、石母田以来武士の領主的な性格を重要視する余り、在地領主が武士という暴力装置であることを無視されているとする批判も出されるようになった。
sen.e: Some criticisms argued that since Ishimoda's theory, the samurai's function as the local lord's had been too emphasized and the fact that the local lord was a part of a violent military system of samurai had been forgotten.

Some critics have argued that since Ishimoda's theory emerged, the samurai's function as local lords had been emphasized too much, and the fact that the local lord was a part of a violent military system of samurai had been forgotten.
sen.cmt: shortened to improve clarity
sen.e: Some critics have argued that since Ishimoda's theory emerged, the samurai's function as local lords had been emphasized too much, and the fact that the local lord was a part of a violent military system of samurai had been forgotten.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
